title: 105_s512
content: The Act may be cited as the "Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998" and it addresses identity theft. The "Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998" amends Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code to include penalties for knowingly transferring or using another person's identification without lawful authority for unlawful activities. The "Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998" amends Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code to include penalties for transferring or using another person's identification without lawful authority for unlawful activities. This includes offenses involving the transfer or use of means of identification resulting in obtaining anything of value aggregating $1,000 or more during any 1-year period. The amendment to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code includes penalties for offenses related to drug trafficking crimes, international terrorism, and crimes of violence. Penalties include fines, imprisonment up to 25 years, or both, depending on the offense committed. The amendment to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code includes forfeiture of personal property used in committing offenses and specifies circumstances where the prohibited actions affect interstate or foreign commerce. The amendment to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code defines terms like "document-making implement" and "identification document" for the purpose of prohibiting their production, transfer, possession, or use. The amendment to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code defines terms related to identification documents and means of identification, including names, social security numbers, and government-issued IDs. The curr_chunk defines terms related to identification documents, including unique biometric data, electronic identification numbers, and personal identification cards issued by State or local governments. It also includes the definition of "produce" as altering, authenticating, or assembling documents. The curr_chunk discusses the inclusion of States in the definition, penalties for attempting or conspiring to commit offenses, and forfeiture procedures under Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code, including a rule of construction for identification documents and conforming amendments to Chapter 47. SEC. 3. RESTITUTION. Section 3663A of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include fraud and related activity in connection with means of identification or identification documents as offenses eligible for restitution to victims. The amendment to Section 3663A of title 18, United States Code, allows victims of fraud involving identification documents to receive restitution for costs incurred, such as attorney fees and credit history clearing. SEC. 4. AMENDMENT OF FEDERAL SENTENCING GUIDELINES FOR OFFENSES UNDER SECTION 1028. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to establish appropriate penalties for offenses under section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. Factors considered include the number of victims and harm caused by the offense. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to establish penalties for offenses under section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. Factors considered include the number of means of identification involved, the value of the loss to individuals, the range of conduct covered by the offense, and the adequacy of sentencing enhancements to ensure punishment near the maximum penalty. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend Federal sentencing guidelines for offenses under section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. Factors considered include the extent to which guidelines achieve sentencing purposes and any other appropriate factors. SEC. 5. Centralized complaint and consumer education service for victims of identity theft. The Federal Trade Commission will establish procedures within 1 year of the enactment of this Act to log complaints from individuals who believe their identification has been stolen, provide information to these individuals, and refer complaints to relevant entities, including consumer reporting agencies and law enforcement agencies. The Federal Trade Commission will establish procedures to log complaints from individuals who believe their identification has been stolen and refer complaints to relevant entities, including consumer reporting agencies and law enforcement agencies. Appropriations are authorized for carrying out this section. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL AMENDMENTS TO TITLE 18, UNITED STATES CODE. This section includes technical corrections related to criminal forfeiture procedures and updates the offenses for wire interception. Passed the Senate on July 30, 1998. The document is attested by Gary Sisco, Secretary.
